awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to California State University San Marcos, located in San Marcos, CA, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. This intensive research program will focus on the unifying theme of Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) and Beyond: From Beetles to Beer. Students will select a mentor from a diverse team of scientists who use genomic, transcriptomic, metagenomic, and epigenomic methods to address fundamental biological questions, including biological control, yeast biology in beer flavoring, soil microbiomes in agriculture, amphibian ranavirus pathogenesis, and biomineralization in invasive coccolithophores. The residential program will foster a community of scholars who will transition from being students to researchers, and from learning to discovery. Weekly enrichment activities are embedded in the program with seminars, bioinformatics workshops, and field trips, to highlight the breadth of NGS applications. In addition to graduate school and career workshops, a culminating Poster Showcase is planned to celebrate research accomplishments of participants and encourage future presentations at regional and national meetings.
 
It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program in conducting and presenting independent research. With a strong commitment to supporting underrepresented groups, including veterans, and first-generation college students, the CSUSM NSF REU program will contribute to building a diverse and talented population of next generation scientists. We hope to host a strong cohort of biologists that will be well poised to apply to competitive doctoral/Masters programs.
 
A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure, and a tri-weekly assessment of applying knowledge to research will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://www.csusm.edu/bioreu/index.html, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Betsy Read at bread@csusm.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Arun Sethuraman at asethuraman@csusm.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report NSF

REU Site: Next Generation Sequence: From Beetles to Beer

Cal State University San Marcos, (2019-2022) Award Number: 1852189

Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, Cal State University San Marcos’ (CSUSM) REU site “Next Generation Sequencing: From Beetles to Beer” was successful in meeting each of its program goals. The 10-week residential summer program was held in person each year between 2019-2022, apart from 2022 when we were obliged to cancel the program. The major goals of the REU: Next generation Sequencing: From Beetles to Beer were to: 1) provide exciting hands-on research opportunities for 30 undergraduate students to   work alongside faculty mentors using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) tools and technologies to address a variety of questions in the biological sciences, 2) promote a sense of community by fostering student-faculty interactions and discussions on the complexities and significance of NGS, 3) motivate and prepare students for graduate school and successful careers in the Life Sciences, 4) provide opportunities for undergraduate biology majors from smaller institutions lacking the infrastructure to support cutting-edge research, and 5) support and improve the educational quality of talented students from underrepresented minority groups in the biological sciences, veterans, first-generation college students and those with challenges that create obstacles to academic success 

REU participants were recruited from across the country in a highly competitive process with 10 students selected each year from ~150 applications.  Of the 32 participants selected over the course of the funding cycle, 72% were female, 78% were from institutions outside of CSUSM, 50% were from institutions with limited resources such as small liberal arts or community colleges, 62.5% were from URM groups, 19% were Black or African Americans, 34% were Hispanic, and 12.5% were Asian. These participants worked alongside faculty using genomic, transcriptomic, metagenomic, and epigenomic methods to address fundamental questions across the biological sciences. Enrichment activities including research seminars, field trips, and activities focused on development of various soft skills, and academic and career exploration. Bioinformatics/ Manuscript Writing workshops promoted a sense of community, encouraging student-interactions and discussions around the complexities and power of NGS in the biological sciences. Cohesiveness and inclusivity were also created during fun informal extracurricular activities including a Juneteenth scavenger hunt, a moonrise hike, grunion hunting, sampling excursions, and a beach barbeque; while campus visits to PhD granting institutions and various local industries, lecture series, and panel discussions motivated and primed students for graduate school and successful careers in the life sciences. The residential program fostered a community of scholars who transitioned from being students to research scientists, who moved from learning to discovery.

Nearly all of the NSF-supported REU participants have completed their Bachelor of Science degrees in STEM  (97%) and a significant portion (~30%) are pursuing advanced degrees including PhDs and MDs. Others are employed in academic institutions (~20%), the life science industry (~30%), or environmental agencies (~`10%). Additional accomplishments that highlight the impact of the REU program on the academic and professional development of participants, and the enhancement of science and technology more broadly, include the 11 manuscripts published by the group, seven of which are directly related to work initiated at CSUSM. 26 of the 32 participants (~80%) are co-authors on at least one published manuscript, 6 (~20) are co-authors on two or more publications, and most have presented at regional or national conferences.

Formative and summative evaluations were performed each year to assess and improve the program. Results from these evaluations suggest “The Next Generation Sequencing and Beyond: From Beetles to Beer” program at CSUSM successfully integrated research and education to promote discovery and understanding. The program effectively trained interns providing them with access to cutting-edge experimental and computational tools and techniques, instilling confidence in their ability to contribute to science; and share of their knowledge, thoughts, and ideas. Data also suggests the program has enhanced participation, retention, persistence, and success in the classroom while fostering confidence, innovation and leadership. And finally, the career progress of our REU alumni, indicates the program with a strong commitment to supporting underrepresented groups, has helped build a diverse and talented population of next generation scientists essential for maintaining our global leadership and competitiveness in science and technology.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2024
Modified by: Betsy A Read
